description: From Middle French dispositif and its source, Latin dispositus. Compare Piedmontese dispositiv.

adjectives.description: dispositive (comparative more dispositive, superlative most dispositive)

entries.meaning: Intending to or resulting in or capable of disposition (disposing of or settling a matter).
examples: We were unable to produce any dispositive evidence to support our case.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) By natural disposition, having such an inclination.
(Euro-English or non-native speakers' English) Being a statutory provision not mandatory to the parties, as in ius dispositivum.

examples: Apollinaire thus used some of the characteristics of the cinematographic and phonographic dispositives and their variables related to viewing or listening apparatuses that preceded or are contemporary to the cinema.
